comment_text: Bring back the long form videos! Or at least post the SciShow podcast on YouTube.
Such a cool woman!!!

U of M? That be Michigan? Mississippi? Missouri? Maine? Minnesota? Maryland? Massachusetts? Can't be Montana. There's only sheep in Montana. :) :) Jellyfish? Come to Illinois and go collecting at Mazon Creek. The Francis Creek Shale member iron siderite concretions have very well preserved jellyfish and other invertebrates. Jellyfish (Essexella Asherae) are as common as dirt. If you can't find one then your eyes are closed. I lied. Blind people find them all the time.

Crazy hypothesis: What if currents got really strong where they were and they developed armour so they wouldn't get quite so smashed up by the currents bashing them against rocks, but then because their had armour, other things that wanted to eat them had to develop jaws?

Hank's question of what the fish were armored against In the silurian period sparked a memory of some kind of sea scorpion. The reason the fish is armored is because of these guys;
Eurypterids
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurypterid
They were the giant apex predators of the silurian period. It was claws not jaws that these fish for protecting themselves from.

I forgot, but I do have fossils, so many, not a huge variety because where i live has some specifically weird geologic history, but the ones we have I find, and the ones we don't I use more of my paycheck on than is probably reasonable. Glacial deposits covering old seas and volcanic activity layers in the middle of america get some weird results rockhounding, but not super exciting, unless you really love sea lilies and coral fossil, then we are set.

To Hank's suggestion about automating bone/rock separation: if someone can make the sieve a bit more precise (i.e. one bit comes out at a time), then it should just be a matter of "place under microscope, perform image processing to determine features of bones, categorize sample, repeat". Of course, I'm way oversimplifying, but that's the gist of it! :D

I volunteer in the Archaeology museum at my college and we are in a similar position. There are artifacts we've had for decades that haven't been processed yet. There are also some things that are probably junk but we can't throw them away because we aren't sure what they are or where they came from anymore.

My father was an exploration driller and miner, he found dozens of fossils in his career, including specimens now in The National Museum of Wales. His big claim to fame is that he worked on the original David Attenborough "Life" series, setting off dynamite and selecting fossils for the host to "find"

Hank, you're assuming ideas (such as an intelligent designer) that aren't part of evolution. Traits aren't "strategies" of animals to adapt. Traits are random and are then selected, for a variety of reasons. The ONLY thing required for a trait to  perpetuate is that it not be so detrimental as to render the species extinct.
